Reviews.Content: This hotel ranks high with me ( solo female American/ experienced traveler) because the price is amazing for the Latin Quarter, the oldest part of Paris. It is so close to 3 Metro stops and 2 blocks from the bustling Bvd. St. Germain and Bvd. Saint Michel with top notch restaurants and shops. Easy to walk to Notre Dame, the Louvre, etc. Easy to get to everywhere and near the beautiful historic Pantheon, Musee Cluny, the Sorbonne etc. Staff is EXTREMELY helpful, multilingual and pleasant. They made my stay memorable.

Reviews.Title: “A hit and miss kind of place?”
Reviews.Author: parisencore
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Hotel Claude Bernard St Germain twice, once in October 2001 and again in January 2003. Reading the reviews, coupled with my own experience and the good reports from a good friend, I think this hotel might be hit and miss. It's larger than many of the typical hotels in Paris so there always seem to be rooms available here when they're hard to find elsewhere, which is a good thing if you need a place to stay. However I wonder if that's because there are some bad rooms here, as has been my experience. It's an OK place for the price, and it felt like a bargain a few years ago before the USD slid. It's nothing fancy, has a very generic vibe and gets a wide range of visitors from large family groups to shopper girls to singles. First stay I had a single room for a week, the teensiest room ever. Bed against two walls with about 1 foot to the window and about 2 foot wide walkway between the fourth side of the bed and the tiny desk. There was no place from which to view the little wall-mounted TV comfortably except if I sat at the inner corner of the bed where the walls met, and even then I had to crane my neck uncomfortably. At least they had TV5 on their cable back then and there were lots of French runway fashion programs! Every morning at 7am I could hear the woman in the next room having her daily half hour conversation with her husband back home. That ensured I got an early start each and every day, like it or not. Also had the teensiest bathroom with a shower not much more than 24" square in plan. Great water pressure and temperature, though. Staff was friendly, genuinely so, helpful, and it was great that they spoke English. They seemed like college students perhaps. Breakfast was always nice in the sunny, windowed room. A nice environment in which to begin the day. Orange juice from concentrate, decent coffee, average croissants if there were any left, yogurt, American-style cereal and milk, cheese square packets. I heard they offered eggs but nobody said a thing to me about it and I didn't ask. I met an American writer there who was staying there for 3 weeks. Pretty good location near useful Metro stop. Note that you have to transfer to get to the department stores so don't buy too much to bring back with you or have them send it to the hotel for you! (Also I try to avoid transferring at Chatelet because it's a nightmare.) Second stay I had a room on an upper floor at the end of the hall for 3 nights. It was a double room this time and it was typical Paris size, not super small like the first room. However I could hear something in the adjacent building all night long. Sounded like an elevator running sporadically, or a washing machine. I really should have asked to move after the first night but I thought it might be a one-night thing. Wrong. My mistake for not asking to move because I couldn't sleep well at all during my time there. The cable selection was not so great this time: No TV5 any longer, luckily two or three French channels (one of which showed very old shows from the US!), but mostly channels from Middle Eastern countries with lectures, reading of the Koran, and panel discussions that are interesting only for a short while if you don't speak the language because there aren't any visuals to give you context or meaning. At first I thought that might have been because of the customer preference but then I saw mostly Asian and European customers on that visit. The bathroom with tub/shower was typical in size however the floor and tub felt grimy. I suspect that the hotel just does not clean rooms as regularly or meticulously as they should. The soap amenities were super cheap and very drying, and were clearly downgraded since my earlier visit. On this visit the coffee was now being made and dispensed from a mini vending machine contraption and the quality was definitely inferior to that of my first visit. Decent coffee is a big thing for me and a dealbreaker, so going someplace else for breakfast would be a necessity for me. Breakfast setup was otherwise the same and otherwise acceptable. The staff was friendly but since I didn't ask about room relocation I don't know how amenable they would have been. Perhaps there are less desirable rooms here that remain unoccupied some of the time and they don't take such good care of them? Or maybe the larger, family sized rooms are maintained better? Just a hunch I have, because there seem to be some good rooms here but I haven't gotten them them. I am really hesitant to try this place again especially if I am not alone -- wouldn't want to disappoint a guest with me.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel - Highly Recommended”
Reviews.Author: paulcellist
Reviews.Content: We found this hotel quite by chance after our reserved hotel across the street turned out to have some problems-(elevator broken - 4th and 5th floor rooms - no offer of help...!) Thank Goodness, as we were given a very clean, pretty room with balcony, to sleep 4. We also took 3 other rooms for the rest of our family group. All had balconies and the rooms on the end were just great with balcony views up and down Rue des Ecoles and of Notre Dame. Staff was very friendly and helpful at breakfast and front desk. We were made to feel very much at home. Breakfast very good - and in a wonderful sunny room with street views. Deserves a much higher rating. We will definitely return.

Reviews.Title: “Claude Bernard - nice rooms, great location and friendly staff”
Reviews.Author: francetravel
Reviews.Content: We loved this place! It had the friendliest and most helpful staff I ever met at a hotel - both at reception and during breakfast. We had 2 good sized rooms (although I did see a tiny double), a double and a triple, with A/C which worked well and bathrooms with either cloth shower curtains or glass doors. While there was an elevator, it only went to the 5th floor, whereas we were on the 6th, but it was very quiet up there. The rooms are all non-smoking and the colors were muted and pretty. There were pretty desks in each of our 2 rooms - they looked more home-style than hotel-style - and our beds had wrought iron headboards. There were also small refrigerators in each room, stocked with 2 small bottles of water. Excellent breakfast - typical croissants and 2 types of baguettes, but also yogurt, cereal, cheese, and eggs with a boiler you use yourself to cook the eggs to your liking. The breakfast room was absolutely beautiful in peach and terra cotta colors and the man who serviced it through breakfast was as nice a guy as you could ever imagine. The only 2 negatives were that two of the pillows were a bit hard and lumpy (although we could still sleep on them, and I'm sure they would have been happily changed if we would have asked), and the wallpaper was a bit marked up in places, but that was easily overlooked too and did not detract at all from the great experience we had here. (I mention the walls because I guidebook I read mentioned them, but we wouldn't have noticed this otherwise.) The location was excellent - an easy walk to Notre Dame, and about 2 blocks from the Pantheon and the metro. There was a boulangerie across the street. Prices were what got us there in the first place - they had a summer special on the Internet for 88 euros for a double including breakfast, and 118 euros a night for the triple (148 for Friday), with breakfast included and the 5th night free. We were pleasantly surprised by this hotel and would definitely go back, even at normal prices.

Reviews.Title: “HATED the DINGY HOTEL BERNARD”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was by far the worst hotel I have ever encountered. The entire place is dingy and the manager is rude. Do yourself a favor, pay an extra $15 and stay in any of the other area hotels. It will be well worth it!

Reviews.Title: “Unfortunate ending”
Reviews.Author: ArtCJW
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel in June, 2004. It was somewhat disappointing. The exterior was lovely, interior clean, breakfast very adequate, rooms normal Paris size, but I had trouble getting the triple room requested. Instead, they just added a petite cot to the twin bed room. I asked about another room and they said they would try to move us. It never happened. In addition, the hotel staff promised to confirm an airport shuttle reservation that I had previously booked. They reported that it had been done. The morning we left, two shuttles arrived from different companies. They had obviously called a second company and never cancelled the reservation I had made. Consequently, I was charged for both shuttle services. When we pulled away from the hotel in one van, the hotel manager and unhappy shuttle service employee where arguing and flailing their arms at each other. Sad ending to a nice Paris visit.

Reviews.Title: “Always Good”
Reviews.Author: Val_in_Boston
Reviews.Content: This is a great little hotel in the Latin Quarter that I've returned to several times. It is a 3*, but above the typical European hotels in this same category. The location is absolutely perfect as I prefer the Latin Quarter and the rooms have always been generous and with new bathrooms. The staff has been consistently kind.
